morphRiver 0.1.0
  • Get started
  • Reference

    A glimpse of the package morphRiver

    L.Vaudor

    4 decembre 2018

    morphRiver.Rmd

    We’ll use the package morphRiver thoughout this document:

    library(morphRiver)

    Data

    Let us consider points (loaded from a shapefile) and a DEM (loaded from a .tif file)

    points=st_read(system.file("data/points.shp", package="morphRiver"))
    ## Reading layer `points' from data source 
##   `/home/lvaudor/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/4.3/morphRiver/data/points.shp' 
##   using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
## Simple feature collection with 101 features and 1 field
## Geometry type: POINT
## Dimension:     XY
## Bounding box:  xmin: 1968189 ymin: 8980512 xmax: 1979458 ymax: 8988157
## Projected CRS: Mercator_2SP
    rasterDEM=raster(system.file("data/rasterDEM.tif", package="morphRiver"))

    Here is a view of the data in these files

    plot(rasterDEM)
plot(points,
     add=TRUE, col=1)

    Curvature

    Calculate curvature

    Only the set of points is needed to calculate curvature:

    rcurv_points=curvature(points)
rcurv_line=rcurv_points %>% points_to_linestring()
print(rcurv_points)
    ## Simple feature collection with 101 features and 2 fields
## Geometry type: POINT
## Dimension:     XY
## Bounding box:  xmin: 1968189 ymin: 8980512 xmax: 1979458 ymax: 8988157
## Projected CRS: Mercator_2SP
## First 10 features:
##            S          C                geometry
## 1     0.0000 0.00000000 POINT (1968189 8980512)
## 2   271.7679 0.18780026 POINT (1968192 8980784)
## 3   483.3461 0.24070411 POINT (1968234 8980991)
## 4   658.5553 0.18949596 POINT (1968309 8981150)
## 5   881.8871 0.30817020 POINT (1968441 8981330)
## 6  1116.5029 0.03284197 POINT (1968630 8981469)
## 7  1429.3279 0.12292599 POINT (1968876 8981662)
## 8  1779.9013 0.38776949 POINT (1969123 8981910)
## 9  2087.9385 0.10982857 POINT (1969242 8982195)
## 10 2413.6805 0.21891594 POINT (1969333 8982507)

    Show result

    … on a map 

    plot(rasterDEM)
plot(rcurv_points["C"],
     add=TRUE, cex=2, pch=20)
plot(rcurv_line["C"],
    add=TRUE, lwd=3)

    … as longitudinal signal 

    library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data=rcurv_points, aes(x=S,y=C))+
  geom_path()

    Calculate basin width

    Calculate elevation

    To calculate the elevation we need the set of points as well as the raster DEM

    relev=elevation(points,rasterDEM) %>% points_to_linestring()
print(relev)
    ## Simple feature collection with 99 features and 3 fields
## Geometry type: LINESTRING
## Dimension:     XY
## Bounding box:  xmin: 1968191 ymin: 8980648 xmax: 1979458 ymax: 8988157
## CRS:           NA
## # A tibble: 99 × 4
##       id     S     Z                                                geom
##    <int> <dbl> <dbl>                                        <LINESTRING>
##  1  2001  272.   181 (1968191 8980648, 1968192 8980784, 1968213 8980888)
##  2  2002  483.   181 (1968213 8980888, 1968234 8980991, 1968272 8981070)
##  3  2003  659.   181 (1968272 8981070, 1968309 8981150, 1968375 8981240)
##  4  2004  882.   181 (1968375 8981240, 1968441 8981330, 1968535 8981399)
##  5  2005 1117.   181 (1968535 8981399, 1968630 8981469, 1968753 8981565)
##  6  2006 1429.   181 (1968753 8981565, 1968876 8981662, 1969000 8981786)
##  7  2007 1780.   180 (1969000 8981786, 1969123 8981910, 1969183 8982053)
##  8  2008 2088.   180 (1969183 8982053, 1969242 8982195, 1969288 8982351)
##  9  2009 2414.   180 (1969288 8982351, 1969333 8982507, 1969418 8982660)
## 10  2010 2763.   180 (1969418 8982660, 1969502 8982813, 1969533 8982973)
## # ℹ 89 more rows

    Transects

    Calculating the basin width requires calculating the series transects going through our points:

    transects_sf=transects(points,500)
transects_sf
    ## Simple feature collection with 99 features and 2 fields
## Geometry type: LINESTRING
## Dimension:     XY
## Bounding box:  xmin: 1967694 ymin: 8980737 xmax: 1979957 ymax: 8988655
## Projected CRS: Mercator_2SP
## # A tibble: 99 × 3
##       id                           geometry     S
##  * <int>                   <LINESTRING [m]> <dbl>
##  1  2001 (1968690 8980737, 1967694 8980831)  272.
##  2  2002 (1968711 8980839, 1967758 8981143)  483.
##  3  2003 (1968736 8980890, 1967882 8981410)  659.
##  4  2004 (1968793 8980976, 1968088 8981685)  882.
##  5  2005 (1968933 8981071, 1968327 8981866) 1117.
##  6  2006 (1969210 8981289, 1968543 8982034) 1429.
##  7  2007 (1969536 8981627, 1968711 8982193) 1780.
##  8  2008 (1969713 8982029, 1968770 8982361) 2088.
##  9  2009 (1969794 8982313, 1968873 8982701) 2414.
## 10  2010 (1969972 8982641, 1969033 8982986) 2763.
## # ℹ 89 more rows
    plot(rasterDEM)
plot(points,
      add=TRUE, col=1)
plot(transects_sf,
     add=TRUE, col=4)

    Basin width

    To calculate the basin width we’ll need to provide both the points and the DEM raster (the function transects() is used internally):

    rwidth=basin_width(points,rasterDEM, radius=500)
print(rwidth)
    ## Simple feature collection with 99 features and 2 fields
## Geometry type: LINESTRING
## Dimension:     XY
## Bounding box:  xmin: 1968143 ymin: 8980777 xmax: 1979494 ymax: 8988220
## CRS:           NA
## # A tibble: 99 × 3
##        S     W                           geometry
##    <dbl> <dbl>                       <LINESTRING>
##  1  272.  123. (1968265 8980777, 1968143 8980789)
##  2  483.  162. (1968328 8980961, 1968174 8981011)
##  3  659.  110. (1968361 8981118, 1968267 8981175)
##  4  882.  151. (1968498 8981273, 1968391 8981380)
##  5 1117.  153. (1968670 8981417, 1968577 8981538)
##  6 1429.  124. (1968918 8981614, 1968836 8981707)
##  7 1780.  112. (1969166 8981881, 1969073 8981945)
##  8 2088.  163. (1969321 8982167, 1969167 8982221)
##  9 2414.  144. (1969392 8982483, 1969259 8982539)
## 10 2763.  190. (1969568 8982789, 1969390 8982855)
## # ℹ 89 more rows

    Show result

    … on a map 

    plot(rasterDEM)
plot(rwidth,
     add=TRUE, col=4, lwd=3)

    … as longitudinal signal 

    library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data=rwidth, aes(x=S,y=W))+
 geom_path()
